{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3357445,"name":"Tony","username":"field","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/field/{size}/223328_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T13:28:34.294Z","cooked":"

Hello!

I’m preparing an updated swerve base for our team’s next robot. We had pretty good success with YAGSL this year, and we are now looking to roll our own codebase to remove outside dependencies.

High praise to the YAGSL team though - the more we learned about swerve the more we understood what the library was doing and why - it’s a very nice library and I would recommend it to newcomers. The documentation has gone from “not really there” to amazing as well. Gold star to that team!

Anyway… I’m looking for a clean explanation as to what ChassisSpeeds.discretize() does. The javadoc doesn’t really help me understand what it’s doing, and I don’t understand the significance of what’s going on under the covers when I decompile it and stare at the math.

We have chosen to split our swerve code into two: a low-level drive base that only understands driveRobotOriented(ChassisSpeeds), and all of the code that knows about heading correction and field-oriented drive. The idea is that the low-level library can “perfectly” do what driveRobotOriented(ChassisSpeeds) asks, with minimal drift when properly tuned, and it’s up to the subsystem that uses the low-level code to handle mapping field-oriented drive and all of those “convenience” features into a robot-oriented drive input value.

This leads me to wonder where (and if) I should be calling ChassisSpeeds.discretize(). Would it belong in the lower-level base that just drivesRobotOriented, or does it belong with convenience features that do things like heading correction, rotating towards headings, etc.

Aside - we’re looking at layering our code like this:

  • SwerveSubsystem uses RunnymedeSwerve
  • VisionAwareSwerveDrive extends FieldAwareSwerveDrive
  • FieldAwareSwerveDrive extends CoreSwerveDrive
  • CoreSwerveDrive implements RunnymedeSwerve

FieldAware and VisionAware relate to odometry and positioning only, and not field-oriented drive. The subsystem handles that.

Any explanation about ChassisSpeeds.discretize() would be greatly appreciated. Comments on our project also welcome.

Thanks!
Tony

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-04-10T13:29:28.729Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":220,"reads":237,"readers_count":236,"score":1142.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":462069,"topic_slug":"looking-for-an-explanation-of-chassisspeeds-discretize","display_username":"Tony","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/math/kinematics/ChassisSpeeds.html#discretize(edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.ChassisSpeeds,double)","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ChassisSpeeds (WPILib API 2024.3.2)","clicks":15}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63070,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-an-explanation-of-chassisspeeds-discretize/462069/1","custom_user_title":"Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3357892,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-10T18:28:37.621Z","cooked":"

Consider a hypothetical swerve robot translating in a straight line while rotating around its center. The chassis velocities required to do that follow sinusoids (i.e., they continuously vary). The robot code can only update the velocity commands at discrete intervals, so the actual robot follows an arc away from the desired path.

ChassisSpeeds.discretize() compensates for the discretization error by selecting constant translational and rotational velocity commands that make the robot’s arc intersect the desired path at the end of the timestep, where the desired path has decoupled translation and rotation.

Here’s an annotated version of the source code:

static ChassisSpeeds Discretize(units::meters_per_second_t vx,
                                units::meters_per_second_t vy,
                                units::radians_per_second_t omega,
                                units::second_t dt) {
  // Construct desired pose after timestep that's relative to current pose. Note
  // that translation and rotation are all decoupled.
  Pose2d desiredDeltaPose{vx * dt, vy * dt, omega * dt};

  // Find chassis translation/rotation deltas in robot frame that move robot
  // from current pose to desired pose
  auto twist = Pose2d{}.Log(desiredDeltaPose);

  // Turn position deltas in robot frame into average velocities in robot frame
  return {twist.dx / dt, twist.dy / dt, twist.dtheta / dt};
}

Note that this only cancels out one cause of drift from the desired path. Another cause is the swerve’s feedback controllers not keeping up with the commands.

field:

Would it belong in the lower-level base that just drivesRobotOriented, or does it belong with convenience features that do things like heading correction, rotating towards headings, etc.

Just like with swerve module heading optimization, all swerve code should be using this.

Thanks @calcmogul - that is exactly the type of explanation I was looking for!

This also explains why the robot rotates in the simulator if we are translating and rotating quickly at the same time. Another mystery solved!
